utterances: (SOUNDBITE OF PRESS CONFERENCE)
The only reason most of these people have not planned another 9/11 at Guantanamo Bay is because they've been in jail.
You let them out of jail, they're going to be on the ground floor planning another 9/11.
And Arizona's John McCain, who now leads the Armed Services panel, has done something of an about-face on Guantanamo.
The former Vietnam prisoner of war argued for years that Guantanamo was a blight on the U.S.
image around the world.
He now says many being held there are too dangerous to be released.
(SOUNDBITE OF PRESS CONFERENCE)

We're going to continue to release batches of prisoners, according to this administration, with no plan and the extreme likelihood that approximately one out of every three of them will reenter the fight.
We owe the men and women who are serving in the military better protection than that.
At the White House today, Press Secretary Josh Earnest said only about 6 percent of the detainees released during the Obama administration had returned to the battlefield.
Holding prisoners at Guantanamo, he said, only helps jihadists recruit more followers.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
This is a very difficult policy problem.
And it's only been made more difficult by members of the United States Senate who have thrown up obstacles to the president's effort to try to close the prison.
An effort that the White House has vowed will continue.
David Welna, NPR News, Washington.
And we'll have more analysis on the global security risk related to Yemen tomorrow morning.
That's where Morning Edition's David Greene will talk with an expert who says extremists are taking advantage of that country's lack of security infrastructure.
The United States women's soccer team now has its third consecutive Olympic gold medal.
The U.S.
played Japan yesterday in London.
When those teams met last year in the World Cup, the Japanese won a tie-breaking shootout.
This time, the U.S.
scored early and held on, 2-1.
NPR's Howard Berkes was there.
At the moment of victory...
(SOUNDBITE OF CHEERING CROWD)
UNIDENTIFIED ANNOUNCER #1: The USA, 2; Japan, 1.
USA are the Olympic champions.
(APPLAUSE)
American superstar Abby Wambach walked over to midfielder Homare Sawa, embraced her, and leaned in to say something over the roar of the crowd of 80,000.
I told Sawa, thank you for letting us have this one.
I couldn't have been more proud to play against Japan because in our opinion, they're the other best team in the world.
Wambach spoke with an Olympic gold medal, and American flag, draped around her neck.
Some of the American players wore T-shirts with the phrase ""Greatness Has Been Found."" That was after the game but early on in it, in the eighth minute of play, an unexpected greatness began.
(SOUNDBITE OF CROWD)
American forward Alex Morgan dribbled the ball just inbounds near the Japanese goal, then shot the ball across her body and toward the front of the goal.
Abby Wambach was there and raised a foot to kick it, but Carli Lloyd flew past, butting it in with her head.
(SOUNDBITE OF ROARING CROWD)
I saw that one coming and, you know, I was hovering around the box.
And I just took off on a sprint and sprinted past Abby, and just made sure it went in.
And it was a great feeling.
Now, here's the thing about Carli Lloyd - she was a benchwarmer before the Olympics; not quite ready for prime time.
Another player was injured, and she was called up.
And to underscore the wisdom of that, in the 54th minute, Lloyd did it again; firing a shot from just outside the penalty box, and beyond the outstretched body of Japanese keeper Miho Fukumoto.
American coach Pia Sundhage.
Carli Lloyd, from being out of the team, sitting on the bench; coming in - and made the difference.
And she went all the way to be a little bit more attacking, and scored two goals.
She has proven that I was wrong before the Olympics.
And I'm really happy that she is more clever than I am.
But there was much more to the game than this.
Japan dominated possession - controlling the ball close to 60 percent of the time, launching attack after attack, and scoring in the 63rd minute.
American goalie Hope Solo had a very busy night blocking shots, and saved the game for her team with nine minutes to go.
(SOUNDBITE OF ROARING CROWD)
Hi, Liane.
You've been traveling again.
(SOUNDBITE OF FLAKO'S ""LULLABY"")
You don't get so enthusiastic about a country like that that you ignore a big buildup of debt, which is what Argentina's main problem was.
Eventually, Argentina's debt became so huge, it couldn't pay its bills.
The peso collapsed, and so did the economy.
Since then things have been quite miraculous, with stunning economic growth, more than 9 percent a year for three years.
But, analyst Kerner says, no one should think that Argentina's economic problems are over.
The situation for Argentina still remains pretty bad.
I mean, the real vulnerabilities of the Argentine economy will reappear, and I think it will be seen that the vulnerabilities are even worse than they were in 2001.
He says that Argentina has, for the most part, just been lucky.
Argentina sells a lot of commodities whose prices have gone up dramatically.
The country's politicians have still refused to fix the many problems that caused the last crisis.

Both Kerner and Blustein says right now things look great, but it seems likely that Argentina will find itself in another crisis soon, and that's when they'll go back to the IMF and ask for another loan.
Adam Davidson, NPR News.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Melissa Block.
The company behind the ubiquitous BlackBerry wireless e-mail devices took a hit today on Wall Street.
Stock in the company Research In Motion tumbled after a ruling by a federal judge in Virginia.
The judge ruled against R-I-M, or RIM (pronounced rim), in a long-running patent dispute with a tiny company called NTP.
The decision revives the possibility that BlackBerry service could be shut down in the US.
NPR's Jim Zarroli is following the story.
And, Jim, tell us first about the dispute that led to today's ruling.
Well, this is just simply a very bitter patent dispute.
Research In Motion is the company that makes BlackBerrys; been very successful with them.
A few years ago, the company was sued by a little Virginia-based company called NTP; it was started by a Chicago engineer who died last year.
NTP claimed that Research In Motion infringed on its patents for wireless devices and in 2001, it sued the company in federal court.
And what is NTP trying to get from Research In Motion?
Well, it asked for an injunction that would basically prevent Research In Motion from operating its BlackBerry service in the US market.
Now NTP has always said that it's willing to negotiate with Research In Motion, but Research In Motion didn't want to negotiate with it.
So there was a court trial in 2002, and a jury basically ruled in NTP's favor; it said Research In Motion had infringed on its patents.
And today, another ruling, this time from a federal judge in Virginia.
What did he say?
Well, earlier this year, after the jury ruled against Research In Motion, the two companies reached a preliminary settlement.
It would have meant hundreds of millions of dollars for NTP, but they couldn't work out the final details and NTP came back to court, saying it wanted to back out of the deal.
Neither side has said why things fell apart, but they did.
So today, the judge, Judge Spencer, basically said there was no settlement, whi--so that leaves everything back at square one.
And then how do they figure this out?
What does the judge or the court do from here?
Well, the judge has already granted an injunction against the BlackBerry company, which would have meant it couldn't operate in the US market, but it was stayed.
Now Research In Motion is saying the judge should continue to stay the injunction because the US Patent Office is reviewing NTP's claims.
And if they can just get the judge to delay any action until the claims are heard, you know, they may be able to kind of run ahead of this, this suit.
But the judge made clear that he thinks this thing has dragged on too long as it is.
Now we said there's a possibility that Research In Motion will actually have to shut down its BlackBerry service.
How real a possibility is that?
It is possible.
I think what's more likely is that the two sides are going to return to the bargaining table.
Research In Motion really has its back against the wall at this point.
They have to offer something better.
For one thing, there are big competitors out there like Motorola and Nokia which are trying to get a part of the wireless e-mail market.
They would dearly love to get a piece of BlackBerry's business.
So Research In Motion really has to negotiate at this point.
And, Jim, in the interest of full disclosure, I don't have a BlackBerry.
Do you use one?
Oh, yeah.
I do, yeah.
I have one that is also a telephone, and it's kind of--it's very convenient.
You know, Melissa, you can actually use them in the New York City subways right now, at least when you're going through some of the stations.
If you have nothing better to do.
Thanks a lot, NPR's Jim Zarroli in New York.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Michele Norris.
